title: Day 1: raw sequence reads to gene counts
text:
On day 1 of this workshop series, we will introduce you to the data pre-processing pipeline for bulk RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) using the command line. To perform differential gene expression analysis, we first need to process raw sequence data to generate a gene count matrix that represents gene expression levels. To do this, we will run the nf-core/rnaseq Nextflow pipeline on Pawseyâ€™s Nimbus Cloud.
All materials copyright Sydney Informatics Hub, University of Sydney

title: RNA-Seq using Nextflow: Day 1
text:
Today we answered a lot of questions:

What is RNA sequencing and what are itâ€™s main applications?
What are the main steps we perform to process raw RNA-seq data to raw gene counts?
How can workflow management tools make running bioinformatics workflows easier?
How to run the nf-core/rnaseq pipeline and interpret its outputs?
What are the important features of the nf-core/rnaseq pipeline?

On day 2, we will learn about differential expression analysis and functional annotation of differentially expressed genes. Weâ€™ll still be working on Nimbus, but instead of working on the command line, weâ€™ll be using R/RStudio.
